# US news roundup: 23-29 January

By Anna McKie

Share

 Share on Facebook
 Share on X
 Share on BlueSky
 Share on Linkedin
 Share via email

Image: Grace Gay for Research Professional News

This week: Trump signs off science budget, CDC databases paused and controversy over autism committee

In depth: The United States’s withdrawal from the World Health Organization threatens “decades of progress” in global health and weakens the cooperation vital for research into infectious diseases, experts have warned.

Full story: ‘Decades of progress’ threatened by US withdrawal from WHO

#### The Neurodiverse Campus

#### The Data Informed Campus

#### A Toolbox for Student Affairs

#### Surviving as a Small College [...] By Len Gutkin

A new report calls the field out for its radical politics.

The Trump Agenda

Education Dept. Says San Jose State Violated Title IX as Enforcement Ramps Up

By Sophia Bailly

The department’s Office for Civil Rights proposed a list of demands that it said would rectify the alleged harms caused by a transgender woman’s participation on the volleyball team.

Education Technology

Can AI Improve Intro Courses? A New Courseware Project Hopes So.

By Beckie Supiano

Learnvia, started by Carnegie Mellon University and backed by the Gates Foundation, says its AI-enabled tools can save professors’ time and help students make quicker progress.

Flurry of bills

Another Red State Wants to Shake Up Higher Ed This Year

By Aisha Baiocchi [...] Working for Change: Solving the Nursing Shortage

UPCOMING: February 24, 2 p.m. ET | What role can higher ed play in combating the nation’s nursing shortage? Join us for a virtual forum exploring how colleges can strategize with local governments and other stakeholders to help improve the nursing pipeline. With Support From Ascendium. Register now.

Chad Crowe

_Hanover, N.H._

Families across the U.S. are questioning whether a four-year degree is worth it. Student debt has soared. Recent graduates are struggling in a rapidly changing job market. Colleges can also be too ideological: On many campuses, students are exposed to a limited range of perspectives, signaling to them what rather than how to think.
